subject: Cooking
title: Marco Polo Didn't Bring Pasta from China
description: A micro-lesson that makes Marco Polo Didn't Bring Pasta from China usable.

hook.text: Everyone learns that Marco Polo brought pasta from China to Italy in 1295. There's one problem: it's not true.

buildup.text: A 1929 American magazine article invented the story for entertainment. It was never in Polo's actual writings.

discovery.text: Italian documents from 1279 mention pasta â€” before Polo returned from China. Arabs brought it centuries earlier.

twist.text: Both Italy and China developed noodles independently â€” pasta in Italy from durum wheat, noodles in China from millet.

climax.text: The oldest known noodles are 4,000-year-old Chinese millet noodles found preserved in an earthquake-sealed bowl.

punchline.text: Marco Polo didn't invent Italian pasta. A 1929 magazine did.

quiz.question: Who actually introduced pasta to Italy, according to historians?
